Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Advanced Nonlinear Control of ac/dc Micro Grids

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to build a quality research program to develop advanced nonlinear
controllers using artificial neural networks that have assured performance for the emerging ac/dc micro
grids. The proposed research is associated with educational activities and a well-defined plan for
technology transfer to industry. The micro grids comprise of conventional fossil-based generators along
with significant penetration of highly intermittent renewable energy sources as well as storage devices.
The approach is to develop nonlinear models of the proposed micro grids, followed by nonlinear control
schemes leading to assured grid stability. Next, pertinent simulation and hardware implementation of the
proposed controllers will be performed.
Intellectual merit. The proposed work shall focus on fundamental challenges of ac/dc micro grids
including proper modeling, centralized and decentralized nonlinear control, and assured stability using
distributed generation, FACTS devices and storage. Moreover, the PI will develop new undergraduateand
graduate-level courses on ac/dc power systems. Publications in related journals and conferences will
continue.
Broader impact. Near and long term impacts of the proposal?s outcomes include allowing widespread
utilization of renewable sources through efficient control designs, technology transfer to industry,
dissemination of the course materials to other institutions, as well as control design for other complex
applications such as Dep. of Trans., wireless networks, etc., through employing the experience obtained
in this work on complex systems control. In addition, a set of outreach activities including engagement of
women and under-represented minorities through Louisiana Student Diversity Programs' office and K-12
outreach are planned

POR.DRECONTENT:
New developments in the renewable energy technologies, distributed storage, demand-side load management, and advances in employing renewable energy sources such as wind, solar, ocean, etc., have provided new opportunities to reduce the dependency on fossil fuels while exploiting ambient energies. The existence of renewable energy sources in the power grids provides more reliability by making the energy available in outages. Moreover, these sources of energy, when combined with storage, can optimize the energy flow by providing a flatter daily energy production trend. However, these emerging technologies have imposed great control challenges on the power systems. Most of the renewable energy generators used in power systems such as wind turbines and solar cells employ rectifiers and inverters. Such systems employ dc components. When dc components are connected to the conventional ac power grid, an ac-dc power system results. The future power system will be an ac-dc power system with significant penetration of dc components due to recent advances in renewable energy technologies and affordability of such energy generators in residential as well as industrial sectors. Among major components of future power systems are the micro grids. Micro grid facilitates the distributed generation and exploitation of the renewable energy sources in residential, commercial, and industrial places. It can include conventional power plants (diesel, gas, or steam,) renewable energy sources (wind turbines, solar cells, fuel cells, etc.,) ac and dc networks, storage, and ac and dc loads such as electric vehicles (EVs). However, the conventional power system stability methods have been mainly developed for single frequency, ac power systems with traditional synchronous generators and cannot be directly utilized for ac-dc micro grids. Also, a micro grid can be a multi-frequency power system as the frequency of the wind turbine-generators is usually different from that of the ac consumers and traditional power plants.

            In this project, innovative approaches and associated educational activities are conducted to properly model and control the ac-dc microgrids using advanced nonlinear control and artificial neural networks. Subsequently, through simulation, the developed models and controllers are carefully tested and verified followed by hardware implementation of the developed controller on a lab version ac-dc micro grid. Detailed models of ac-dc power systems are developed and proper nonlinear controllers are obtained for both ac-dc power systems and dc networks using neural networks. The stability of such controllers are proven using nonlinear control theory.

 

Intellectual merit. The conducted research focuses on fundamental challenges of ac-/dc micro grids including proper modeling, centralized and decentralized nonlinear control, and assured stability using distributed generation, FACTS devices and storage. Moreover, the PI has developed new undergraduate- and graduate-level courses on ac-dc power systems. Publications in related journals and conferences has been accomplished. 

Broader impact.  Near and long-term impacts of the proposal’s outcomes include allowing widespread utilization of renewable sources through efficient control designs, technology transfer to industry, dissemination of the course materials to other institutions, as well as control design for other complex applications such as Dep. of Trans., wireless networks, etc., through employing the experience obtained in this work on complex systems control. In addition, a set of outreach activities including engagement of under-represented minorities and K-12 outreach are performed.
